lessons.title: Risk vs Return
lessons.description: This is a little explanation of what the module is about

steps.title: Welcome Back! üëã
steps.content: Financial ratios are like a company's report card. They tell you if a business is healthy, profitable, and worth your money

steps.title: What Are Financial Ratios? üßÆ
steps.content:
Think of ratios like comparing apples to apples.
Instead of just saying 'Apple made $10 billion,' ratios help you compare: 'Apple made $10 billion with $50 billion in sales vs Netflix made $2 billion with $8 billion in sales.'

Who's more efficient?
The ratios tell the story!

steps.title: The Big 3 Ratios You Need üéØ
steps.content:
Don't worry! You don't need to memorize 50 ratios!
Focus on these game-changers:
  • P/E Ratio - Is the stock expensive or cheap?
  • Debt-to-Equity - Is the company drowning in debt?
  • ROE - How good is the company at making money?

P/E means that if a stock costs $100 and the company earns $5 per share yearly, P/E = 20.

Quick rule: P/E under 15 = potentially cheap, P/E over 25 = potentially expensive. But remember - growth companies often have higher P/Es!

steps.title: Debt-to-Equity - The Stress Test ‚öñÔ∏è
steps.content:
DTE shows how much debt a company has vs. its own money.
Healthy range: 0.1 to 0.4 (company owns most of its assets)
Yellow flag: 0.5 to 0.8 (manageable but watch closely)
Red flag: above 1.0 (more debt than equity: risky!)

Banks and real estate can handle more debt than tech companies.

steps.title: ROE - The Efficiency Master üìà
steps.content:
Return on Equity = How much profit a company makes with shareholders' money.
  • 15-20% ROE¬†= Excellent (the company is a money-making machine!)
  • 10-15% ROE¬†= Good (solid performance)
  • Under 10% ROE¬†= Meh (might want to look elsewhere)

steps.title: Where to Find These Numbers üîç
steps.content: No math required! These ratios are already calculated for you.

steps.title: Real Example - Let's Practice! üí°
steps.content:
This is an example with Apple:
  • P/E Ratio: 28 (a bit expensive, but Apple has strong growth)
  • Debt-to-Equity: 0.31 (healthy - Apple isn't drowning in debt)
  • ROE: 26% (excellent - Apple is super efficient!)


Conclusion: Expensive but high-quality company. Perfect for long-term growth!

steps.title: Quick Comparison Trick üèÜ
steps.content:
Pro tip: Never judge a ratio alone! Always compare:
  • Same industry (compare Netflix to Disney, not to banks)
  • Company's history (is this normal for them?)
  • Market conditions (growth vs. recession times)
Context is everything in investing!

steps.title: You're Done! üöÄ
steps.content: You now understand the three most important financial ratios. These tools will help you avoid expensive traps and find quality companies.

questions.question: A tech startup has a stock price of $50 and earns $2 per share annually. What is its P/E ratio, and how would you categorize it?
questions.explanation: P/E = Price √∑ Earnings = $50 √∑ $2 = 25. Since 25 is at our ~expensive~ threshold of 25+, it's potentially expensive (though normal for growth companies).

questions.question: You're researching two companies. Company X has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.3, while Company Y has 1.2. What should you think?
options: Company X is healthier; Company Y is a red flag
Company Y is healthier; Company X is too conservative
You need more information to decide
questions.explanation: 0.3 is in the healthy range (0.1-0.4), while 1.2 is above 1.0, which means Company Y has more debt than equity - a red flag!

questions.question: Which company would Warren Buffett likely prefer based on ROE alone?
questions.explanation: 22% ROE is in the ~excellent~ range (15-20%+), showing the company is very efficient at generating profits with shareholders' money.

questions.question: You want to check Apple's financial ratios quickly. What's the BEST approach from the lesson?
options: Calculate them manually from the annual report
Check Yahoo Finance or Google AAPL stock
Wait for the quarterly earnings call
questions.explanation: The lesson emphasized that ratios are already calculated for you on sites like Yahoo Finance or by googling the stock ticker.

questions.question: You found a restaurant chain with a P/E ratio of 35. Before deciding if it's expensive, what should you compare it to?
options: Other restaurant chains and the company's historical P/E
questions.explanation: The lesson's pro-tip emphasized comparing within the same industry (other restaurants) and to the company's own history for proper context.

lessons.title: Research Methods
lessons.description: It's time to become an investment detective...

steps.title: Welcome Detective! üïµÔ∏è
steps.content: You've learned to read charts and understand the numbers, but how do you actually research a company before investing? Let's uncover the secrets that separate smart investors from gamblers.

steps.title: The 3-Layer Research Approach üéØ
steps.content:
Think of company research like buying a house. You wouldn't just look at the price, right? Smart investors use 3 layers:

  • Layer 1: The Business - What do they actually do?
  • Layer 2: The Competition - Are they winning or losing?
  • Layer 3: The Future - Where are they headed?
This takes just 15-20 minutes per company!

steps.title: Layer 1 - Understanding the Business üè¢
steps.content:
The 5-Minute Business Check:
  • Read the company description on their website
  • Check what % of revenue comes from their main product
  • Ask: 'Could I explain this business to my friend?'
üö© Red flag: If you can't understand what they do after 5 minutes, skip it. Stick to businesses you 'get' - Apple, Netflix, McDonald's make sense!

steps.title: Layer 2 - Checking the Competition üèÅ
steps.content:
Quick Competitive Analysis:

  • Google: '[Company name] competitors'
  • Compare market share numbers
  • Look at who's growing faster
  • Check recent news for 'wars' (streaming wars, phone wars)


Pro tip:¬†The best companies often have a 'moat'. Something competitors can't easily copy (like Coca-Cola's brand or Apple's ecosystem).

steps.title: Layer 3 - Future Potential üöÄ
steps.content:
The Crystal Ball Questions:
  • Is their industry growing or shrinking?
  • Are they investing in new technology/products?
  • Do they have plans for new markets?
  • What do experts predict for next 3-5 years?
Where to look: Company earnings calls, industry reports, tech blogs. Don't predict the future - just understand where they're headed.

steps.title:
Your Research Toolkit üõ†Ô∏è

Free Research Souces (Bookmark These!):
steps.content: Time budget:¬†20 minutes max per company. If you need more, it's probably too complicated!

steps.title: Putting It All Together - Tesla Example üîç
steps.content: Conclusion:¬†Innovative company in growing industry, but increasing competition. Good for risk-tolerant investors who believe in EV future.

steps.title: Great Job! ‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®
steps.content:
Now you have a full toolkit to research any company or stock you are interested in.

Let's put that knowledge into test.

questions.question: According to the lesson, what are the three layers of company research in the correct order?
questions.explanation: The systematic approach is: Layer 1 (The Business - understand what they do), Layer 2 (The Competition - are they winning?), Layer 3 (The Future - where are they headed?).

questions.question: When researching a company's business model, what's the key red flag mentioned in the lesson?
options: The company has been around for less than 5 years
You can't understand what they do after 5 minutes
They have more than 3 main products
Their website is difficult to navigate
questions.explanation: The lesson emphasized: if you can't explain the business to a friend after 5 minutes of research, skip it. Stick to businesses you understand.

questions.question: What is a 'moat' in business terms, as mentioned in the lesson?
questions.explanation: A 'moat' is a competitive advantage that's hard for competitors to copy, like Coca-Cola's brand recognition or Apple's ecosystem.

questions.question: According to the lesson, how much time should you spend researching one company?
options: As much time as needed, no limit
questions.explanation: The lesson emphasized 20 minutes max per company. If you need more time, the investment is probably too complicated for beginner investors.

questions.question: Based on the Tesla example in the lesson, what was the main concern identified about Tesla's future?
options: Electric vehicles are a shrinking market
Increasing competition from GM and Ford
They don't have global expansion plans
questions.explanation: The lesson noted that while Tesla is ahead in EVs, their competitive advantage is shrinking as traditional automakers like GM and Ford catch up.
